segments.text: things that I recall that were important to him and things that he considered important.

I made a speech to the Sol Ross group in March of 91, and I'm looking at my notes now, and I had under his accomplishments in the mid-60s coeducation, integration, the name change, the non-compulsory core, and my comment here was he felt he had to sacrifice some of his own
deep-rooted feelings to do what was best for the school.
And then I told a little story about LBJ and what his remarks were.
I had notes here that Beaumont Aggies threatened to burn all their diplomas.
I think one or two actually did.
There were a few rings and diplomas mailed back.
Then I had state and federal support look at his connections, LBJ and the White House, John Connolly.
I had land office to A&M, then Tiger Teague and Bill Moore as far as financing.
And I wrote with these connections, A&M had support like no other school in America.
In the 60s, we were put on the map of higher education.
He was very proud of beginning the faculty buildup, the first National Academy of Sciences faculty member.

At the time that the Students for a Democratic Society were disrupting the campus in Colorado and at Berkeley, he had Bob Melcher say, Melcher, oh, some bitch is going to send somebody down here to stir us up.
And I want you to tell me exactly who the first one is.
And it turns out it was a little redheaded boy.
And Melcher said, here's your SDS leader.
And he said, I want him in my office tomorrow morning.
And the little boy was very nervous.
I saw him.
And after a discussion which went something like this, son, I know who you are.
I know why you're here.
And I want you to know that what you're hoping to do here is not going to work.
And this fat old man here that's president of this school is going to be the first one
after you with a club if you start any kind of disruption.
And then later, word got out that some SDS colleagues from Austin were going to come over and disrupt final review.
And Mr. Rutter saw to it that a story got out.
It did not come from the president's office.
But it got to the SDS, the little handful that we had.
to the effect that at final review, there would be some unmarked vans parked around the drill field.
And the school had nothing to do with it.
This is just a rumor that they would be filled with Aggie football players with baseball bats just aching to find someone to disrupt final review.
And then no disruption took place.
The enrollment explosion began, and I did some little figures here that might be interesting.
In the decade of the 50s, the total enrollment was up 546 students.
Decade of the 60s, it went up to 7,095 students.
In the decade of the 70s, it went up 19,183 students.
And I had a little note that I signed while I was dean of admissions, 15 years.
90,121 diplomas, which was 58.8% of those awarded since 1878.
So that was just an example of the growth.
Then on his habits, thoughts, and feelings, rudder now.
Motto for Aggies, the difficult we do immediately, the impossible takes just a bit longer.
I mentioned the smooth operations with the board.
deep and abiding faith in former students, closeness unparalleled.

And I remember that one day Mr. Zachary was in his office, and things were kind of tough at the time, and I remember Mr. Zachary stood and said, Earl, there'll be times when you're present here that you're going to need something badly.
He said, when you want something very badly, whatever it is, then you call me.
As far as you know, did he ever do that?
Probably on political support for funding, yes.
Probably so.
Used him for political .
Are you aware of any major frustrations he had with the board where maybe he and the board did not end up agreeing?
No.
I've never heard of any.
If they had them, they worked them out.
Things were going really so well, and he and the board got along so well.
They're real, as I remember, and I was over there at that building, you'd hear little comments from Wells or whoever.
The comments would be things like, Earl, what can we do for you at this meeting?
It was for you.
you the universal.
Now, describe his process, his political process, for Austin or Washington.
How did he go about getting things done there?
Well, he had the most marvelous set of contacts you could possibly imagine, starting at the top and going down through the governor and the state senators and what have you.
I think to start with, he would call them up and tell them what he had in mind and say, is this going to fly?
And if it's not, you tell me what I have to do to make it fly.
And he would do it directly, not through an intermediary.
Usually not.
He knew them as well as.
Oh, yeah.
Did we have anybody officially then representing us?
In Austin, you mean, or Washington?
I can't think of it.
No, no, no, it was one on one as best I can remember.

The, uh, one other little thing on my notes here about rudder that I told those boys that would be a good story for you to have is I was in his office one day and I may have told you this before and Abner McCall called him and he just did like this meant to stay there in my chair and they finished their business on the phone.
And finally, we were playing Baylor at College Station that week, and this was like Thursday.
And he said, Abner, what are those damned old mean bears of yours going to do to our poor little old Aggie Saturday?
And he paused, and he nearly fell out.
I've never seen him laugh that hard.
But Abner McCall, he told me, said, Earl?
We're going to beat the hell out of you, but we're going to do it in a Christian-like way.
Your basic question, what was he proudest of?
Construction of the facilities that we needed.
He got that started.
He began the program for getting the first few stellar type of faculty.
always with the hope that we could have really good ones that kept at the classroom level.
He kept harping at that.
And the funding in Austin and otherwise, and including former students.
He was a marvel with former students.
He would go to their, and not many presidents have done this since then, he would go to their
Annual meetings, the executive committees, and he would sit there and talk to them just like we're talking right now.
And I don't think anyone has really done that that effectively since then.
He paid attention to them and made them feel very good, and in turn, he could call them.
You name Beaumont, you name Port Arthur, you name a town, he had somebody influential there that he could call because he made himself one of them.
And one of the things that he looked to me for, and Williams did it even more than, than Rutter.
He wanted me at those meetings, especially when he couldn't be there.
He wanted someone from his office there that had his ear.
To represent.
Yeah.
Now, uh, during the early sixties, uh, I understood that at first, uh, particularly that year when Marion Pugh was running for the Senate against Bill Moore, that supposedly
President Rutter and Moore supposedly were not completely in agreement.
That's right.
But they worked out.
Do you know how that?
They kind of clashed on this, that, and the other.
But they got along well enough that Moore could say, Earl, I'm going to vote this way on a given subject, and here's why.
And you're just going to have to.
Bear with me on that.
I know you don't like it, but I've got to vote.
And, but, but they would talk and say, well, we disagree on this, but here's what we're going to do now.
Here's a, where does that thing?
I was just going, yeah, here's a, was an interesting meeting right here.
That's Evans rudder.
And this is when they legislature decided they were going to get involved.
and whether or not A&M was coeducational.
And I am telling you the truth.
What is it?
That's my birthday.
Oh, it is?
That was a tough time because they allowed people up in the bleacher seat, what do you call it, balcony, get up and make impassioned talks and this, that, and the other.
But the, let me get this straight, a very pretty lady
set up a desk in the hallway leading to the Senate chamber.
And she knew how every one of the senators, what position they were going to take on coeducation.
And this lady represented a group opposed to it.
And as a senator would come up, she would call him over and suggest that if he needed entertainment that night,
that if he would vote the right way, that she could sure damn sure arrange that.
That was a standing joke.
And she was opposed to coeducation.
Now, do you remember?
She was with a mother's club.
Was there a vote?
Did they vote?
I think they took.
A non-binding?
Yeah, a non-binding kind of vote.
And that's what this terrible night was there, because it just went back and forth.
It was just terrible.
When it turned out, what was that non-binding vote?
Do you remember?
No, I don't remember.
No, I better not say.
I don't remember.
But it was such a wishy-washy thing, so mixed up, that it didn't amount to a hill of beans.
And they knew they didn't have the rightful authority to make that decision.

Now, I have heard that during that period, just by sheer coincidence, that on certain nights at about 10 o'clock at night, two cars would pull up beside each other facing opposite directions with the driver's side windows almost touching in the parking lot just on the north side of the campus theater.
And with their lights off, these two total strangers would chat with each other

that one of them happened to be a state senator and the other one happened to be a university president have you ever heard that no i heard that that that bill moore and mr rutter sometimes would chat their person to person face to face no i did not if that happened i don't know about it uh let's see was there any important person that mr rudder listened to uh
who was a pronounced opponent of those changes?
Any of his close friends, advisors?
I've never heard of one.
And there was no board member who became well known for his opposition.
Once a word came back from
LBJ, the way that it did, I think people just said, well, what the hell?
Mrs.
Rudder's role during those years, describe her as the wife and mother.
Whenever I'm around her and there's someone new between us there, she will tell them.
Edwin here was the first person
at A&M that paid any attention to the president's wife.
And on his first function, which was some kind of a little coffee or something, he came over to me and said, everybody's paying attention to the president over there.
Is anyone paying any attention to you?
And she never forgot that.
We had a close relationship, the four of us.
We went out to their ranch a couple, three times, dove hunting, the four of us, when he just needed to get away.
She was frustrated at him because he did not want to look bad on paper in terms of what it cost to operate that president's home.
He tried valiantly and succeeded to a large extent to get most of it given.
I think that president's home cost the state of Texas $63,000.
And he took great pride in that.
She had to operate on a

just threadbare basis and the board never did appropriate enough money to operate that thing and yet they they expected to be wind and dying there when they when the spirit moved them and it's it was tough on williams as well as rudder now the they were living when you became the system they were living in the old president's house they were the one that burned burned and my best story about that is when
Tiger T, in particular, came to see them.
He had to have a bottle of whiskey.
That's just the way it is.
So Mr.
Rudder had a Pan Am flight bag with a couple of bottles of bourbon in it that he hid way back in his closet.
And he was desperately afraid that the students or faculty would find out that the president had whiskey in his house.
And so he hid it in that Pan Am bag in the night.
that Joe and Peggy Hollingsworth were married across the street in the all-face chapel.
We were there.
And that night, later, that place burned.
Yes, ma'am?
Are you?
OK. You going where?
I'm going to a mess.
A mess?
Reunion group.
OK. All right.
See you later.
Be right back.
The fire started between the chimney and the frame.
And the rudders got back from wherever they were while she was really
boiling up in flame and in spite of warnings from the fire people, he roared into that house and retrieved that Pan Am bag and got out of there.
I think he had actually burned hair in his effort to prevent the scandal of whiskey being found on that campus.
He's

later i think the board said now look earl when they built the new house uh you've got to entertain so just forget about this phobia about whiskey because when we come over we want it too and so he he he finally set up a little bar there but he sure was careful about who saw it now in the old house did they lose a lot of their furniture and possessions they sure did
The students went in and saved a lot of things.
One was a piano that I remember.
But they really lost a lot of personal things.
They really did.
And it was a hardship on them.
It really was.
Now, where did they live after the fire?
On Lee Street.
In a two-story White House in the first block of Lee Street on the left-hand side as you go south.
And the school just rented that for them until they built the other one.
He went to great lengths to get as much of the new and built free of charge as he could, and donations from alumni.
And he did a tremendous job on that.
He wanted it facing east.
He did that.
And John, I mean, Connolly.
What's his from?
Connolly Moving and Storage.
Donald and Doug.
Moved him from Lee Street to his home at no cost.
That was his gift.
And then a few months later, Peg and I finished our little home down Pershing Street.
And Conley Brothers moved us, and I said,
OK, what's the bill?
And he said, the same thing that Mr. Rutter got.
Oh, how nice.
How nice.
And in those days, $10 was a, I mean, we had kids out at the kazoo.
And that was really a generous kind of a thing.
Those are really the things to me that he was proudest of, the beginning of a new faculty, the higher caliber faculty, the financial support required to really move the school, the connections to get
big time people like Werner Von Braun and the first astronauts here.
He took great pride in those kind of things, associating the students with what was great, who was great in America at that particular time.
There have got to be some memories tucked away in your brain of some of the lighter moments and some of the more serious moments of the Rudder years.

The funniest thing that ever happened was that daughter Jane, I believe it was Jane, fell in love with a real good-looking old boy that was as poor as a church mouse, but handsome, who was a student in veterinary medicine.
And in order to survive, he had to get a job.
He didn't have a car, so it had to be a job on campus.
and he ended up with the grounds maintenance crew.
Do you know this story?
And the grounds maintenance crew had a chalkboard, and they'd say, okay, on Thursday, we're going to be trimming the hedges around the Coke building.
On Tuesday, we're going to be at the library doing this or that.
Well, he looked on there and said, Thursday, you're going to be working in the president's rose garden.
And he was going with Jane and Mr.
Rudder,
was out of town.
And he called Jane and he said, sweetie, I'm going to be working in your Rose Garden Thursday.
Where is your daddy going to be?
And she looked it up and said, he's going to be out of town.
He said, let me have lunch with you there at the house.
You fix lunch for us.
And she readily agreed.
And they came over in an old dump truck.
And I can still see the foreman wore one of those old Texaco hats and khakis buttoned up here.
the 12 o'clock whistle blew.
And he said, come on, boys.
We're going back for lunch.
And this boy threw his hoe down.
He says, I think I'll just have lunch here and walked into the front door.
The poor old man.
The former didn't know whether to shh or go blind.
He didn't know what to do.
And the boy just walked in.
Another thing that was funny that happened, it sure wasn't funny at the time, with his phobia about whiskey on campus.
And we had a deal where I could go to Austin.
When I was in Austin, he said, go by the Liquor Association.
And they have a building in Austin.
And they had a standing offer that I could come over there or someone from Rutter's office and pick up case after case of booze and to bring it back for official purposes.
And so I did that several times.
He would not allow it to be kept at his house, so I kept it in a closet at my house.
And one time, we got down to one bottle.
It was time for another trip to Austin.
Had one good bottle left, and his rule with me was always keep one good bottle.
When he called me, he'd meet me, and I'd give him this bottle, and he would go over to Ramada Inn and give it to Olin E.T., of which they would sit down and drink the entire thing.
So he calls me one Sunday afternoon.
He said, Edwin, get the bottle ready.
I'll be over there in about half an hour.
Tiger's here.
And I had had a party of my own at the house.
And we had consumed most of that bottle, knowing full well it'd be replaced before he'd need it.
So here was the president of the university coming over to get his congressman his bottle of whiskey.
And I was out.
So I ran over to Carl Butler's house by car.
I said, Carl, give me the best bottle of bourbon you've got.
I'll pay you back later.
And boy, he saw the urgency, gave it to me.
And as I drove back onto Texas Avenue, College Avenue, Mr. Rutter and his wife passed by, going straight for my house.
So I came up right behind them.
And I came out with a brown bag.
And I said, I'm embarrassed about the kind of whiskey that we had for the Congressman.
So I prevailed on one of my friends to give us this really top dollar, Paul.
Well, how very nice.
And I never did tell him the difference.
Let me add an anecdote that I heard in Washington, and I cannot remember from what member of the Texas delegation it was.
It was in the 60s, and I was up there doing research on Jefferson Davis, and I went by two or three different Texas congressmen's offices.
Oh, it was Jack Brooks.
And I told him how helpful the Library of Congress had been and so forth.
He knew my A&M connection and that I knew Mr. Rutter and so forth.

And he said that, one, he had witnessed part of, and it's heard the rest of it, that Mr. Rutter was in Washington and that Teague was going to, because he was a committee chairman, he had a big office, and he was going to cook some steaks for certain members of the Texas delegation.
And he had also laid in some alcoholic refreshment.
Mr. Rutter was there.
And while they're cooking and waiting for the others to come, they have a few refreshments.
And they look, and where are all the people?
It's late.
It's late.
And according to Brooks, when he went to his office earlier than usual the next morning, here was the chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee.
and the president of Texas A&M coming down the hallway with their arms around each other singing, goodbye to Texas, because they had gotten mixed up on the night.
It was the wrong night.
And so they said they weren't about to cancel the party.
They didn't cancel the party.
Probably the most emotional thing that ever happened to me
was the day that President Kennedy was killed in Dallas, and I was his assistant.
And every administrator in the Koch building was either in Dallas or somewhere.
And the lowly assistant to the president was the highest-ranking officer in that office that day, and I don't think that had ever happened before.
There's always at least a vice president, or they weren't there.
They were all because of Kennedy's.
So the word flashed that he'd been shot.
And Mr. Rutter was at that Coliseum waiting to be there.
And of course, the word came.
And I ran over to the MSC.
There was no television in that building at that time.
And watched what was on the air and started crying.
Went back to the Koch building, and the first thing I got was a call from one of the deans.
And he was crying, just openly crying on the phone.
He said, I called to find out what we're supposed to do.
I said, I'll tell you what we're going to do.
I'm the only one here.
And that places me in authority.
I said, we're going to close this damn thing down.
And I said, I will call all the other deans and the chief vice presidents all across campus.
And I said, you just consider this school closed as of right now.
And that's what we did.
And probably it was the best thing to do.
And we, if I'm not mistaken, we canceled Bonfire.
Bonfire, right.
And almost beat the Longhorns.
Yeah.
a national championship year.
Let's see.
His relationship with Mr. Teague.
Describe that.
Classmates.
It went way back all the way.
Mr. Teague had a job shoveling
manure out at the cattle and livestock, I'll just say livestock barns, as a way to make money.
And Rudder was a transfer student from Tarleton, but somehow they immediately became friends, classmates, I mean, roommates, I guess.
And Rudder got permission
to stake out a cow somewhere close to where the tennis courts are and sold the milk, I think, to the athletic dorm or something like that.
But they had a great camaraderie going about which one had the most.
Teague claimed that Rudder watered down the milk, and Rudder said,
would always come back with, well, you were out there shoveling shit.
How would you know what I was doing with the milk?
But they were nearly like teenage boys growing up together.
And of course, they had the war experience.
And Teague was made postmaster.
Do you remember that?
And I remember one day I was with him, and he was combing his hair.
And of all things, a little piece of shrapnel had come through the skin.
He got a blast up above him.
And he had shrapnel under the surface.
And he said, that's one of my damn problems.
Every time I comb my hair, a piece of steel comes out my comb.
This while he was a congressman?
Yeah.
But they couldn't have been closer.
And they were always together.
Mr. Teague never had any problems politically as far as I know, you know, getting reelected.
That just wasn't a problem at all.
Judson E. Leupold was his campaign manager always, and people used to say, Tiger, old Lou, he's just kind of a joke.
Why don't you let him do all this stuff for you?
He said, would you go out to be nice, Texas, and
take students out there and nail up posters for me.
Would you do that?
He does.
He does it.
And when I need money, Lupo gets it for me.
So it was a school experience reinforced by military experience, though they weren't together.
And then the relationship between a person in Austin and then
College Station and a man in Washington.
It just couldn't have been closer.
Tiger would argue with him.
I think they had Tiger's biggest problem ever with his constituency.
Guess what?
It was a proposed dam on the Navasota River.
And part of that, I have learned since then, was complicated by a man named Colter Hoppus, who was the originator
of Camp Creek Lake, and this was going to be a country club for the good citizens of Bryan.
And that didn't quite pan out, but right at the end of this road, south entrance road, is the Coulter Office Ranch, which is approximately one-fourth of a mile.
